Why Neutrino Experiments ?
Why Neutrino Experiments ?

• Over the last decade an incredible discovery has emerged in particle physics: Neutrinos have tiny (sub-eV) masses.

Which Neutrino Measurements ?
Which Neutrino Measurements ?

• We don’t know exactly what we need to do to pin
• We don’t know exactly what we need to do to pin

down the physics responsible for neutrino masses, but there is a broad consensus that the first steps for the accelerator-based neutrino program are: – Measure the unknown mixing angle q13 (is it non-zero) ? – Determine the pattern of neutrino masses (mass hierarchy) – Find or constrain CP violation in the neutrino sector
down the physics responsible for neutrino masses,
but there is a broad consensus that the first steps
for the accelerator-based neutrino program are:

A New Type of Neutrino Beam
A New Type of Neutrino Beam

● A Neutrino Factory would provide a new type of neutrino beam, made from muon decays (c.f. charged pion decays for conventional neutrino beams.

Key Experimental Signature
Key Experimental Signature

• Measuring the transitions ne  nm is crucial for the future neutrino oscillation program. • With a conventional neutrino beam this means measuring nm → ne oscillations, and hence ne appearance. With a NF we can measure ne → nm oscillations & hence ne appearance → very low backgrounds
• Measuring the transitions ne  nm is crucial for the future • M e a s u r i n g

Neutrino Factory R&D
Neutrino Factory R&D

•Neutrino Factory R&D pursued since 1997. • Since, in our present designs, the Neutrino Factory and Muon Collider have common front ends (up to & including the initial cooling channel), much of the R&D is in common. •See Bob Palmer’s Muon Collider talk for proton requirements, target, bunching & phase rotation, and cooling design and R&D. • Key experiments:

Bunching, Phase Rotation & Cooling
Bunching, Phase Rotation & Cooling

• After drifting down a 57m long pion decay channel, the muons have developed a time-energy correlation. A clever arrangement of RF cavities captures the muons in bunches & then reduces their energy spread.
• After drifting down a • A f t e r

time-energy

arrangement of RF
cavities captures the
muons in bunches &
then reduces their
energy spread.

Ionization Cooling
Ionization Cooling

• Must cool fast (before muons decay)
• Must cool fast (before muons decay) • M u s t
c o o l
f a s t
( b e f o r e
m u o n s
d e c a y )

• Muons lose energy by in material (dE/dx). Re-accelerate in longitudinal direction → reduce transverse phase space (emittance). Coulomb scattering heats beam → low Z absorber. Hydrogen is best, but LiH also OK for the early part of the cooling channel.

Steve Geer High Intensity Proton Accelerators Fermilab 19 October 2009 25
Steve Geer High Intensity Proton Accelerators Fermilab 19 October 2009 25

FINAL REMARKS
FINAL REMARKS

•International Scoping Study prepared the way for the next step – The International Design Study •The IDS aspires to deliver a NF Reference Design Report (RDR) by 2012. • If the community wishes, after a few more years of preconstruction R&D, neutrino factory construction could begin as early as the late 2010’s • The NF & MC front-ends are, in present designs, the same … and require a 4MW (or more) proton source providing 3ns long (or less) bunches with a rep rate of a few x 10Hz. We believe we have the target technology for this. • Realizing a NF would mitigate many of the technical risks associated with realizing a MC
